title: Erdős Problem #890: Sum of ω over Consecutive Integers
description: Is lim inf S_k(n) ≤ k + π(k) where S_k(n) = ∑ ω(n+i)? Is lim sup S_k(n) · log log n / log n = 1? Known: lim inf ≥ k + π(k) − 1 (Erdős–Selfridge). OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #890 (Erdős–Selfridge, [ErSe67]) studies S_k(n) = ∑ ω(n+i) for 0 ≤ i < k. They proved lim inf S_k(n) ≥ k + π(k) − 1 using Pólya's theorem on k-smooth number gaps. Two open conjectures sharpen the liminf and limsup.
overview.problemStatement: Two conjectures: (1) lim inf S_k(n) ≤ k + π(k); (2) lim sup S_k(n) · log log n / log n = 1. OPEN for general k.
overview.proofStrategy: We define ω(n), π(k), and S_k(n) using Finset operations. Liminf/limsup predicates capture asymptotic behavior. The Erdős–Selfridge lower bound and classical ω limsup are axiomatized.
keyInsights: S_k(n) = ∑_{i<k} ω(n+i) sums distinct prime factors across k consecutive integers
Erdős–Selfridge proved lim inf S_k(n) ≥ k + π(k) − 1 via Pólya's smooth number theorem
The conjectured upper bound k + π(k) for lim inf is tight to within 1
The limsup conjecture generalizes the classical ω(n) result to consecutive blocks
Both conjectures remain open for k ≥ 2

sections.title: Part I: Arithmetic Primitives

sections.title: Part III: Conjecture 1 (Liminf Bound)
sections.summary: ErdosConjecture890_liminf: lim inf S_k(n) ≤ k + π(k) for all k ≥ 1.

sections.title: Part IV: Conjecture 2 (Limsup Ratio)
sections.summary: ErdosConjecture890_limsup: lim sup S_k(n) · log log n / log n = 1.

sections.title: Part V: Known Results
sections.summary: Axioms: Erdős–Selfridge lower bound (lim inf ≥ k + π(k) − 1) and classical ω limsup.

sections.title: Part VI: Summary
sections.summary: Theorem erdos_890_lower_bound: restates the Erdős–Selfridge bound.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #890 studies the sum of distinct prime factors across consecutive integers. The Erdős–Selfridge lower bound is tight to within 1. Both the liminf and limsup conjectures remain open.
conclusion.implications: Resolving these conjectures would reveal how prime factor counts distribute across consecutive integer blocks, extending classical results on ω(n) to a collective setting.
openQuestions: Is lim inf S_k(n) exactly k + π(k)?
Does the limsup ratio equal 1 for all k ≥ 2?
Can the Erdős–Selfridge lower bound be improved?
